# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 435, 89]]<|/det|>
The points \(A, B, C\) have position vectors

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 102, 683, 121]]<|/det|>
\[4\mathbf{i} - 4\mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k},\quad -4\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} - 4\mathbf{k},\quad 4\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 405, 152]]<|/det|>
respectively, relative to the origin \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 821, 183]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the plane \(ABC\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 608, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the perpendicular distance from \(O\) to the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 918, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 186, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 351, 507, 369]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) has position vector \(2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} - 3\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 808, 400]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the point of intersection of the line \(OD\) with the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 771, 92]]<|/det|>
The sequence of positive numbers \(u_{1}\) , \(u_{2}\) , \(u_{3}\) , \(\ldots\) is such that \(u_{1} > 4\) and, for \(n \geqslant 1\) ,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 104, 601, 144]]<|/det|>
\[u_{n + 1} = \frac{u_{n}^{2} + u_{n} + 12}{2u_{n}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 146, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 920, 200]]<|/det|>
By considering \(u_{n + 1} - 4\), or otherwise, prove by mathematical induction that \(u_{n} > 4\) for all positive integers \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 74, 549, 95]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(2x^{3} + 5x^{2} - 6 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 144, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 101, 556, 127]]<|/det|>
Find a cubic equation whose roots are \(\frac{1}{\alpha^3}, \frac{1}{\beta^3}, \frac{1}{\gamma^3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 185, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 536, 411, 562]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{1}{\alpha^6} + \frac{1}{\beta^6} + \frac{1}{\gamma^6}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 452, 109]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{2x^{2} - x - 1}{x^{2} + x + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has no vertical asymptotes and state the equation of the horizontal asymptote of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 185, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 448, 547, 467]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 680, 89]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of the intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 70, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 426, 143, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 415, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{2x^{2} - x - 1}{x^{2} + x + 1}\right|\) and state the set of values of \(k\) for which \(\left|\frac{2x^{2} - x - 1}{x^{2} + x + 1}\right| = k\) has 4 distinct real solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 465, 920, 484]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 633, 102]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^2 = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\theta\right)\), where \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 111, 144, 129]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 109, 818, 131]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state, in exact form, the greatest distance of a point on \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 111, 920, 129]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 917, 415]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the area of the region bounded by \(C\) and the half-line \(\theta = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 405, 920, 423]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 405, 143, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 403, 915, 425]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 210, 487, 228]]<|/det|>
Now consider the part of \(C\) where \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 144, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 608, 260]]<|/det|>
Show that, at the point furthest from the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{2}\pi ,\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 273, 636, 301]]<|/det|>
\[(\theta^{2} + 4)\tan^{-1}\Bigl (\frac{1}{2}\theta \Bigr)\sin \theta -\cos \theta = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 317, 621, 336]]<|/det|>
and verify that this equation has a root between 0.6 and 0.7.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 319, 918, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 94, 92, 112]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 75, 437, 129]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) is given by \(\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & k & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 140, 144, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 139, 584, 159]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which \(\mathbf{A}\) is non-singular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 140, 920, 159]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 186, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 358, 798, 377]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{A}\) is non-singular, find, in terms of \(k\), the entries in the top row of \(\mathbf{A}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 358, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 792, 112]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}\), give an example of a matrix \(\mathbf{C}\) such that \(\mathbf{BAC} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ k & 4 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 81, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 83, 146, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the transformation in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane represented by \(\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ k & 4 \end{pmatrix}\) has two distinct invariant lines through the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
## Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
